## {data-background-image="figs/NYT_Words_Disappear.jpg" data-background-size="contain" data-background-position="center" data-background-opacity="1"}

## Research Questions

- What factors make certain agencies targets for political action?
- How do perceptions of racialization vary between agencies perceived as conservative versus liberal?
- In what ways is racialization distinct from political ideology?

## Contribution

- We develop a new measure of racialization.
- We demonstrate that ideology and racialization are distinct.
- We open up the conversation to key factors that can help explain policy outcomes and the unequal racial effects across agencies.

## Key Takeaways

- Racialized language for a given agency can vary over time, despite stable core missions.
<!-- - Framing processes at work recast missions to emphasize race and inequality.-->
- Racialized language is tied to ideological extremism, reducing perceptions of agency neutrality.
- "Centrist" agencies like FEMA attract less media and elite attention.


## Next Steps

- More Data will allow us to have more dynamic racialization scores over time
- Adding economic redistribution to our measure
